Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what is reverse nakamoto?

Author: zawy#5864
Content: it uses VDF fnuction and POs to replace hashrate with stake rate

Author: zawy#5864
Content: since stake capital is on the chain whereas equipment capital's presence is proven to the chain only after elections, the process has to be reversed to simulate POW

Author: zawy#5864
Content: But still use POW to generate and distribute coin

Author: zawy#5864
Content: with self-hashing txns

Author: zawy#5864
Content: where solo miners select the amount of coin they want to create

Author: zawy#5864
Content: and stakers adjust the difficulty of POW mining as they do consensus on the txns ....so that they can choose a stable value coin without reference to any fiat

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Every block needs the on-chain work to be accurate.   The miner proves he did it by proving he solved something 1/2 that difficult  based on his timestamp and evidence it was a CST-RST block.  This plan still has an error: miners who jump on for the late-time solves did not actually do all the work.  The actual work was actually less, depending on how much miners attampt that.

Author: zawy#5864
Content: A more proper method is to go back to SMAs without the final thing I did which was using nTime ( a tipdiff adjsutment)...we know it can result in too many blocks released due to e^x  and big miners.........but they have the perogative to get more coin becuase they have to pay a much higher difficulty than the miners getting the e^x.    So the ideal solution  may involve adjusting reward based on solvetime to get the stablie emission rate we are attempting with difficulty.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
i encoded whether the CST was triggered or not in the least significant bit of nBits. it will change the diff very slightly, but will just be small noise. this gets us 100% certainity of whether a block was RST_CST or not and it is essentially free to calculate.
have a version in testing that will toggle whether it adjusts the ct[] array and digishield or not, based on that bit. i also added the averaging with prior bnTarget as that seems to prevent the very fast block followed by super hard one and seems to have more consistent results. maybe it slows things down a block or three on hashrate changes, but the volatility at steady hashrate is quite annoying.
assuming this runs stable and the diff converges and there isnt a lot of variance, i will test various changing of hashrate and see how long it takes to adapt

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
as of now, it isnt triggering and it is reflected properly in nBits.
it seems the max() side of SMA might be very useful as there is no mechanism other than exp() to bring the diff down quickly. so a 5x "stranding" would leave it at higher diff for quite a while. not sure if the RST_CST can be made symmetric, or if i should just add back the max() side SMA

Author: jl777c#5810

Content: I need 1000 blocks with knowledge of hashrate to see what we've got.  It's kind of funny to design a DA and not see any results from modelling. But it should be done that way for security.
